question:
Which of the following places was not the centre of the Revolution of 1857 in Rajasthan?

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 2012
solution:
• Among the given options, Jaipur was not a major center of the Revolution of 1857 in Rajasthan.
  • Although Rajasthan witnessed several local uprisings during the revolt, the rulers of princely states like Jaipur remained largely loyal to the British.
  • The Jaipur state did not see any significant rebellion or armed uprising during the revolt.

Key Centres of 1857 Revolt in Rajasthan:

  • Ajmer: Under direct British control, saw active participation in the revolt.
  • Neemuch: A major military cantonment where sepoys revolted against British officers.
  • Auwa: Led by Thakur Kushal Singh, Auwa became a stronghold of resistance and successfully opposed the combined British and Jodhpur forces.

Additional Information:

  • Jaipur’s ruler, Maharaja Sawai Ram Singh II, maintained allegiance to the British.
  • His cooperation helped the British maintain control in central Rajasthan during the revolt.

question:
Who among the following fought against the British in 1857?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2000
solution:
• The correct answer is Shahadat Khan, who fought against the British during the Revolt of 1857.
  • He was one of the regional leaders who actively participated in resisting British rule during this first major uprising.
  • The other individuals listed were freedom fighters of the 20th century, not participants in the 1857 revolt.

Clarification on Other Options:

  • Chandrasekhar Azad – Active in the 1920s and 30s; associated with Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA).
  • Ram Prasad Bismil – Leader of the Kakori conspiracy (1925), part of the HSRA.
  • Makhanlal Chaturvedi – A poet, journalist, and freedom fighter in the Gandhian era (20th century).

Additional Information:

  • Shahadat Khan's name is often associated with central Indian resistance during the 1857 revolt, particularly in present-day Madhya Pradesh.
  • While less prominent nationally, he remains a symbol of regional resistance in the 1857 uprising.

question:
Who among the following was the staunchest enemy of the British in the Revolt of 1857?

45th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• The staunchest enemy of the British during the Revolt of 1857 was Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah.
  • He was popularly known as the "Maulvi of Faizabad" and emerged as a charismatic military and spiritual leader in the Awadh region.
  • He organized and led armed resistance against the British in Lucknow, Faizabad, and surrounding areas.
  • The British feared his influence and called him one of the most dangerous leaders of the rebellion.

Additional Information:

  • Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah had travelled across India spreading anti-British sentiments even before the revolt.
  • He led troops in coordination with Begum Hazrat Mahal and others in Awadh.
  • The British placed a bounty of ₹50,000 on his head due to the serious threat he posed.
  • He was betrayed and killed by the Raja of Powain in 1858.

question:
Which brave man from Bhopal fought bravely and sacrificed his life in the First War of Independence of 1857?

M M.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2019
solution:
• The brave man from Bhopal who fought valiantly and sacrificed his life during the First War of Independence in 1857 was Fazil Muhammad Khan.
  • He was a revolutionary figure in Bhopal, actively involved in organizing resistance against British rule during the uprising.
  • His patriotic actions and sacrifice made him one of the notable martyrs from Madhya Pradesh in the 1857 revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Bhopal was a princely state during the revolt, and while its rulers remained loyal to the British, brave individuals like Fazil Muhammad Khan stood up for Indian freedom.
  • His efforts represent the individual heroism and localized uprisings that contributed to the broader national movement of 1857.
  • The other names listed:
    • Sheikh Ramzan, Dost Muhammad Khan, and Habibullah Khan do not have a direct association with martyrdom during the 1857 revolt in Bhopal.

question:
Which Urdu poet witnessed the revolt of 1857?

45th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• The Urdu poet who witnessed the Revolt of 1857 was Mirza Ghalib.
  • Ghalib lived in Delhi during the revolt and observed the devastation caused by the uprising and its brutal suppression by the British.
  • He wrote about the chaotic atmosphere and destruction of Delhi in his personal letters, providing a first-hand literary account of that period.

Additional Information:

  • Ghalib’s letters written during and after 1857 are considered important historical records.
  • He described the decline of the Mughal Empire, the atrocities committed, and the collapse of cultural and social life in Delhi.
  • The other poets listed:
    • Mir Taqi Mir died in 1810 — before the revolt.
    • Iqbal was born in 1877 — after the revolt.
    • Jok (assumed to be a fictional or unclear reference) is not a known historical figure of that time.

question:
The native place of the famous Urdu poet Mirza Ghalib was-

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2002
solution:
• The native place of the famous Urdu poet Mirza Ghalib was Lahore.
  • Although Ghalib spent most of his life in Delhi, his ancestral roots were from Lahore, which was then part of undivided India (now in Pakistan).
  • He was born in Agra in 1797, but his family originally hailed from Lahore, making that his ancestral/native place.

Clarification:

  • Birthplace: Agra (1797)
  • Residence and poetic career: Primarily in Delhi
  • Ancestral origin (native place): Lahore

Additional Information:

  • Ghalib's full name was Mirza Asadullah Baig Khan.
  • He is regarded as one of the greatest Urdu and Persian poets in Indian literary history.
  • His poetry reflects deep philosophical thought, love, loss, and the decline of the Mughal era.

question:
Who did not participate in the first war of independence in 1857?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2000
solution:
• The person who did not participate in the First War of Independence in 1857 is Bhagat Singh.
  • Bhagat Singh was born in 1907, 50 years after the revolt, and was a prominent revolutionary of the Indian freedom movement in the 20th century.
  • The other three — Tatya Tope, Rani Lakshmibai, and Bahadur Shah Zafar — were all key figures in the 1857 revolt.

Correct Associations:

  • Tatya Tope: General of Nana Saheb, led guerrilla warfare.
  • Rani Lakshmibai: Queen of Jhansi, died fighting the British in 1858.
  • Bahadur Shah Zafar: Mughal emperor, declared symbolic leader of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Bhagat Singh was a member of the Hindustan Socialist Republican Association (HSRA).
  • He was hanged in 1931 for his role in revolutionary activities against British rule.

question:
Who among the following was not associated with the revolt of 1857?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1996
solution:
• Udham Singh was not associated with the Revolt of 1857. He was a revolutionary who avenged the Jallianwala Bagh massacre by assassinating Michael O'Dwyer in 1940 in London.
  • The Revolt of 1857 was the first major uprising against British rule and included leaders such as:
    • Begum Hazrat Mahal – led the revolt in Lucknow (Awadh)
    • Kunwar Singh – a key leader in Bihar
    • Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah – played an important role in Faizabad and Awadh region
  • Hence, Udham Singh belongs to a different time period (20th century) and context (Indian freedom struggle against British imperialism, but not the 1857 revolt).

Additional Information:

  • The Revolt of 1857 is also known as the First War of Indian Independence
  • Other famous leaders: Rani Lakshmibai (Jhansi), Tantia Tope (Kanpur), Bahadur Shah Zafar (Delhi)

question:
Which dynasty helped the British the most in the freedom struggle of 1857?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• The Scindias of Gwalior (a Maratha dynasty) were among the most prominent allies of the British during the Revolt of 1857.
  • Jayajirao Scindia, the ruler of Gwalior at the time, remained loyal to the British, despite some of his own soldiers rebelling.
  • Even when Rani Lakshmibai and Tantia Tope tried to take control of Gwalior, Scindia fled and did not support the rebels.
  • In contrast, other dynasties either remained neutral or their support was unclear.
  • Therefore, the Scindias helped the British the most during the 1857 revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The betrayal or neutrality of some Indian rulers was a key reason for the failure of the revolt.
  • Holkars of Indore also didn’t actively support the revolt but weren't as helpful as the Scindias.
  • Bhonsles of Nagpur had already lost power by 1853 (Nagpur annexed by Doctrine of Lapse).
  • Lodhis of Ramgarh were minor players and had no significant impact.

question:
The educated middle class in India has-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1998
option_1: Opposed the revolt of 1857.
option_2: Supported the revolt of 1857.
option_3: Maintained neutrality during the revolt of 1857.
option_4: Fought against the native rulers.
solution:
• The educated middle class in India during 1857 was still in its early stages of development and was largely influenced by Western education and ideas.
  • This class generally did not participate in the revolt and chose to remain neutral.
  • Many educated Indians considered the revolt to be a backward-looking, feudal uprising led by traditional rulers and sepoys, not aligned with their reformist or modern views.
  • Their support was neither for the British nor the rebels; instead, they observed from the sidelines.
  • Hence, the correct answer is that they maintained neutrality during the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Leaders like Raja Ram Mohan Roy and others had earlier laid the foundation for modern reformist thought, which made the middle class more cautious.
  • The Revolt of 1857 was seen as anti-modern by some educated elites who preferred constitutional reforms over violent uprisings.

question:
Who among the following classes did not participate in the revolt of 1857?

(i) Agricultural labourers

(ii) Moneylenders

(iii) Farmers

(iv) Landlords

Select your answer from the following codes-

40th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1995
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 saw widespread participation from various sections like sepoys, peasants (farmers), and landlords (zamindars) in many regions.
  • However, moneylenders and some zamindars (landlords) largely did not support the revolt.
  • In many cases, moneylenders were actually targeted by the rebels due to economic exploitation.
  • Some zamindars, especially those who benefited under British rule, either remained neutral or supported the British.
  • On the other hand, agricultural labourers and farmers did participate in several areas, especially in rural uprisings that accompanied the main revolt.

Hence, the correct answer is: (d) (ii) and (iv) – Moneylenders and Landlords did not participate.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt had socio-economic undertones, where the grievances of peasants and soldiers found common ground.
  • However, economic beneficiaries under British policies like moneylenders and certain landlords chose not to join.

question:
Who among the following did not revolt against the control of the English East India Company?

B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
option_3: Poligars of Tamil Nadu
option_4: Dewan Velu Thampi of Travancore
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Nizam of Hyderabad was known for his loyalty to the British and did not revolt against the East India Company.
  • In fact, Hyderabad was one of the first princely states to sign a Subsidiary Alliance with the Company (in 1798), ensuring British control in return for internal autonomy.
  • On the other hand:
    • Raja of Vijayanagaram opposed the British and was deposed after resisting them.
    • Poligars of Tamil Nadu (like Veerapandiya Kattabomman) revolted fiercely against Company rule.
    • Dewan Velu Thampi of Travancore led a notable anti-British uprising in early 1800s, famous for his Kundara Proclamation (1809).
  • Therefore, only the Nizam of Hyderabad did not revolt, making option (b) the correct answer.

Additional Information:

  • The Subsidiary Alliance System, introduced by Lord Wellesley, was key to extending British indirect control.
  • Nizam's support helped the British during other regional revolts like the Anglo-Maratha Wars.

question:
Which one of the following areas was not affected by the revolt of 1857?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2005

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Mains) 2006
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 primarily affected northern and central parts of India where there was strong discontent against British rule.
  • The major centers of the revolt included:
    • Jhansi – Led by Rani Lakshmibai
    • Jagdishpur – Led by Kunwar Singh
    • Lucknow – Strongly defended by Begum Hazrat Mahal
  • However, Chittor (located in present-day Rajasthan) was not a center of activity during the 1857 revolt.
  • Although Rajasthan had princely states, most of them remained passive or loyal to the British, and Chittor did not witness any significant uprising during this period.

Additional Information:

  • Other major centers of the revolt were Delhi, Kanpur, Bareilly, Faizabad, and Arrah.
  • The revolt was not uniform across India; south and western India remained mostly unaffected.

question:
Which part of Bihar remained unaffected by the revolt of 1857?

(i) Danapur

(ii) Patna

(iii) Ara

(iv) Muzaffarpur

(v) Munger

Select your answer from the following codes-

41st B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1996
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 had significant impact in many regions of Bihar, particularly:
    • Danapur – One of the early centers where sepoys mutinied.
    • Patna – Witnessed activities of Peer Ali Khan, a revolutionary who was later executed.
    • Ara (Arrah) – Center of a major uprising led by Kunwar Singh.
  • Muzaffarpur also saw limited unrest, though not as prominently as the areas above.
  • However, Munger (also spelled Monghyr) remained largely unaffected by the revolt.
    • It had a British cantonment, but no notable participation or uprising occurred there.

Hence, the correct answer is: (b) Only (v) – Munger remained unaffected.

Additional Information:

  • Kunwar Singh is a celebrated figure in Bihar's contribution to the revolt.
  • The presence of British military and loyal princely elements helped suppress rebellion in areas like Munger.

question:
Match List-1 (Heroes of the 1857 revolt) with List-2 (Their areas of work)-

List-1 List-2

(A) Bakht Khan i. Awadh

(B) Maulvi Ahmadullah ii. Kanpur

(C) Kunwar Singh iii. Arrah

(D) Nana Saheb iv. Delhi

Chandigarh P.C.S (Pre) 2014

Code :

ABCD
option_1: iiiiiiiv
option_2: iiiiiivi
option_3: iviiiiii
option_4: iviiiiii
option_5: iiiviiii
solution:
Let’s match List-1 (Heroes) with List-2 (Areas of work) accurately:

  • (A) Bakht Khan → (iv) Delhi

    He was a subedar in the British army who later led the rebel forces in Delhi during the revolt.

  • (B) Maulvi Ahmadullah → (i) Awadh

    A key religious and revolutionary leader from Faizabad (Awadh region), known for mobilizing forces against the British.

  • (C) Kunwar Singh → (iii) Arrah

    He led the rebellion in Bihar, especially in and around Arrah (Jagdishpur).

  • (D) Nana Saheb → (ii) Kanpur

    He led the revolt in Kanpur and declared himself the Peshwa of Marathas.

So, the correct matching is:

A → iv, B → i, C → iii, D → ii

Hence, the correct code is: (c)

Additional Information:

  • Bakht Khan coordinated with Bahadur Shah Zafar in Delhi.
  • Maulvi Ahmadullah was known as the "Hero of Awadh."
  • Kunwar Singh was over 70 years old during the revolt but still led bravely.
  • Nana Saheb’s associate, Tantia Tope, also played a major role in the revolt in Central India.

question:
Match List-I with List-II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists-

List-I List-II

A. Jhansi Maulvi Ahmed Shah

B. Lucknow 2. Azimullah Khan

C. Kanpur 3. Begum Hazrat Mahal

D. Faizabad 4. Rani Lakshmibai

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2010

Code :

ABCD
option_1: 4321
option_2: 4231
option_3: 3421
option_4: 1234
solution:
Let’s correctly match List-I (Place) with List-II (Associated Personality):

  • A. Jhansi → 4. Rani Lakshmibai

    She was the queen of Jhansi and a key leader in the 1857 revolt.

  • B. Lucknow → 3. Begum Hazrat Mahal

    She led the revolt in Lucknow (Awadh region) after the British deposed Nawab Wajid Ali Shah.

  • C. Kanpur → 2. Azimullah Khan

    He was a close associate of Nana Saheb, who played a central role in Kanpur's uprising.

  • D. Faizabad → 1. Maulvi Ahmed Shah

    A religious leader who led the rebellion in the Faizabad region during the revolt.

So, the correct matching is:

A → 4, B → 3, C → 2, D → 1

Correct code: (a)

Additional Information:

  • Rani Lakshmibai became a symbol of resistance against British annexation.
  • Begum Hazrat Mahal took active command of the rebel forces in Lucknow.
  • Azimullah Khan was educated in England and served as a political advisor.
  • Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah was respected for his leadership and sacrifice in Awadh.

question:
Which of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2018

Location -Leadership
option_1: Sambalpur - Surender Sahi
option_2: Ganjam - Radhakrishna Dandsena
option_3: Kashmir - Gulab Singh
option_4: Lucknow - Liaquat Ali
solution:
Let’s examine each pair to check whether the location is correctly matched with its 1857 revolt leader:

  • (a) Sambalpur – Surendra Sahi✅

    Correct. Surendra Sahi, along with his brother Ujjwal Sahi, led the rebellion in Sambalpur (present-day Odisha) during the Revolt of 1857.

  • (b) Ganjam – Radhakrishna Dandsena✅

    Correct. Radhakrishna Dandsena was a local zamindar who led anti-British activities in the Ganjam region (also in Odisha).

  • (c) Kashmir – Gulab Singh✅

    Correct. Though Gulab Singh, the Dogra ruler of Kashmir, did not support the 1857 revolt, he was the ruling figure during that time. This pair is still contextually valid as he represented the British-aligned leadership in Kashmir.

  • (d) Lucknow – Liaquat Ali❌

    Incorrect. The revolt in Lucknow was led by Begum Hazrat Mahal, not Liaquat Ali.

    Liaquat Ali was the leader of the revolt in Allahabad, not Lucknow.

Hence, the incorrect match is: (d) Lucknow – Liaquat Ali

Additional Information:

  • Begum Hazrat Mahal took charge after the British exiled Nawab Wajid Ali Shah from Awadh.
  • Liaquat Ali was a religious leader who took over the civil administration of Allahabad during the uprising.

question:
Who among the following took active part in the Revolt of 1857?

66th B.P.S.C (Prc) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
Let’s analyze each option to determine who actively participated in the Revolt of 1857:

  • (a) Nana Saheb (Kanpur)✅

    Actively led the revolt in Kanpur, declared himself Peshwa, and took over British establishments. A major figure of the uprising.

  • (b) Begum Hazrat Mahal (Lucknow)✅

    Played a leading role in Lucknow after the British exiled Nawab Wajid Ali Shah. Took control of the city and led rebel forces.

  • (c) Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah (Faizabad)✅

    Known as the "Hero of Awadh," he led the rebellion in Faizabad and Awadh region, gaining both religious and popular support.

  • (d) Begum Zeenat Mahal (Delhi)❌

    Although she was Bahadur Shah Zafar’s wife, her role was not military or administrative in nature. She did not take active part in the revolt.

So, more than one person listed above actively participated in the revolt.

Hence, the correct answer is: (e) None of the above / More than one of the above

Additional Information:

  • All three (Nana Saheb, Hazrat Mahal, Ahmadullah Shah) are regarded as frontline leaders of the 1857 rebellion.
  • Begum Zeenat Mahal's influence was courtly and personal, not revolutionary.

question:
Match List-I with List-II and choose the correct answer from the code given at the end of the lists -

List-I List-II

(Names of revolutionaries) (Place)

A. Nana Saheb Delhi

B. Nawab Hamid Ali Khan 2. Kanpur

C. Maulvi Ahmadullah 3. Lucknow

D. Mani Ram Dewan 4. Assam

U.P.R.O/A.R.O. (Pre) 2016

Code :

ABCD
option_1: 1243
option_2: 1234
option_3: 2143
option_4: 2134
solution:
Let's match List-I (Revolutionaries) with List-II (Places) based on their role in the Revolt of 1857:

  • A. Nana Saheb → 2. Kanpur✅

    He was the main leader of the revolt in Kanpur, where he declared himself the Peshwa and took over British establishments.

  • B. Nawab Hamid Ali Khan → 1. Delhi✅

    Nawab Hamid Ali Khan was one of the nobles who had ties with the Delhi court and was associated with the resistance efforts centered in Delhi.

  • C. Maulvi Ahmadullah → 3. Lucknow✅

    Though originally from Faizabad, he played a crucial role in mobilizing support in the Awadh region, including Lucknow.

  • D. Mani Ram Dewan → 4. Assam✅

    A former official in Assam, Mani Ram Dewan was involved in organizing resistance against British rule in the Assam region.

Additional Information:

  • Mani Ram Dewan was one of the earliest rebels from Assam and was executed by the British.
  • Maulvi Ahmadullah was also called the “Roaring Prophet of Rebellion” for his fierce leadership.
  • Nana Saheb’s revolt in Kanpur was one of the bloodiest confrontations of 1857.

question:
Which one of the following (Place of the Revolt of 1857 - Beginning of the Revolt) is not correctly matched?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2023
solution:
Let’s evaluate each place and date related to the beginning of the Revolt of 1857:

  • (a) Lucknow – 4 June 1857✅

    The revolt reached Lucknow by early June 1857, and 4 June is considered a correct date for its outbreak there.

  • (b) Jhansi – 11 May 1857❌

    This is incorrect. The revolt did not begin in Jhansi on 11 May.

    • The uprising in Jhansi occurred later in June 1857.
    • 11 May 1857 marks the entry of rebel sepoys into Delhi, not Jhansi.
  • (c) Meerut – 10 May 1857✅

    This is the correct starting point of the Revolt of 1857. Sepoys rose in rebellion on the evening of 10 May 1857 in Meerut, initiating the uprising.

  • (d) Barrackpore – 29 March 1857✅

    On this date, Mangal Pandey fired at a British officer in Barrackpore, which is considered a precursor incident to the full-fledged revolt.

Hence, the incorrectly matched pair is: (b) Jhansi – 11 May 1857

Additional Information:

  • Jhansi's revolt began only after British forces moved out, and Rani Lakshmibai took charge in early June 1857.
  • Delhi was captured by rebels on 11 May 1857, the day after Meerut's revolt.

question:
Who was the Governor General of India at the time of the revolt of 1857?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2005

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1990, 2012

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Mains) 2013
solution:
• The Governor-General of India during the Revolt of 1857 was Lord Canning. ✅
    • He held the position from 1856 to 1862.
    • He played a critical role in handling the revolt, and later became the first Viceroy of India in 1858 when the British Crown took direct control from the East India Company.

Let’s evaluate the other options:

  • (a) Lord Dalhousie❌
    • Governor-General from 1848 to 1856, just before the revolt.
    • He introduced policies like the Doctrine of Lapse, which became one of the causes of the revolt.
  • (b) Lord Minto❌
    • Became Governor-General later (1807–1813) and again not related to 1857 events.
  • (d) Lord Bentinck❌
    • Governor-General from 1828 to 1835, far before the revolt.

Hence, the correct answer is: (c) Lord Canning

Additional Information:

  • After the revolt, Lord Canning implemented the Queen’s Proclamation (1858) and ushered in a new era of British Crown rule in India.
  • He was also nicknamed “Clemency Canning” for his relatively moderate post-revolt policies.

question:
Who was the Governor General of India at the time of the Sepoy Mutiny?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2006
solution:
• The Sepoy Mutiny (also known as the Revolt of 1857) was a major uprising against the British East India Company's rule in India.
  • It began in May 1857 in Meerut and soon spread to other parts of North and Central India.
  • At that time, the Governor-General of India was Lord Canning.
  • Lord Canning held the office from 1856 to 1862, and he played a crucial role during and after the revolt.
  • After the revolt, he also became the first Viceroy of India in 1858, when the control of India was transferred from the East India Company to the British Crown.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie was Governor-General before Canning (1848–1856); his annexation policies (e.g., Doctrine of Lapse) were one of the causes of the revolt.
  • Lord Hardinge was Governor-General from 1844 to 1848.
  • Lord Lytton served much later (1876–1880).

question:
Who was the British Commanding Officer at Barrackpur during the 1857 Revolt?

U.P.P.S.C. (R.I.) 2014
solution:
• The Barrackpore cantonment in Bengal was one of the earliest flashpoints of unrest leading up to the Revolt of 1857.
  • The first signs of rebellion were noticed here among the sepoys even before the main revolt erupted in Meerut.
  • During this time, the British Commanding Officer at Barrackpore was General J.B. Hersey.
  • He attempted to suppress the discontent by punishing sepoy Mangal Pandey, who attacked British officers.
  • Mangal Pandey was tried and hanged in April 1857 under Hersey's supervision.

Additional Information:

  • Henry Lawrence was stationed at Lucknow and died during the siege there.
  • Colonel Finnis was killed at Meerut when the mutiny broke out.
  • Sir Hugh Wheeler was the commanding officer at Kanpur during the revolt.

question:
Who made Allahabad the emergency headquarters in 1857?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2005
solution:
• During the Revolt of 1857, the situation in North India became extremely volatile, with Delhi, Kanpur, Lucknow, and other major centers engulfed in rebellion.
  • To manage the crisis efficiently and coordinate military and administrative response, Lord Canning, the then Governor-General of India, shifted his emergency headquarters from Calcutta to Allahabad.
  • Allahabad was strategically important due to its central location and access to the Ganges and Yamuna rivers, as well as proximity to key conflict zones.
  • This decision helped in better command and control during the suppression of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Cornwallis, Lord Wellesley, and Lord William Bentinck were Governor-Generals before the revolt:
    • Cornwallis: Governor-General (1786–1793, again briefly in 1805)
    • Wellesley: (1798–1805)
    • William Bentinck: (1828–1835)

question:
Who was the British Prime Minister at the time of the revolt of 1857?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1991
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 took place during the tenure of Viscount Palmerston as the Prime Minister of Britain.
  • Henry John Temple, known as Lord Palmerston, served as British Prime Minister twice:
    • First term: 1855–1858
    • Second term: 1859–1865
  • The revolt occurred in 1857, during his first term.
  • As Prime Minister, Palmerston supported strong imperial control and was involved in policy decisions post-revolt, including the Government of India Act 1858, which ended East India Company rule and brought India under direct Crown control.

Additional Information:

  • Winston Churchill was Prime Minister during World War II (1940–45 and again 1951–55).
  • Clement Attlee was PM during India’s independence (1945–51).
  • William Gladstone served four terms but none during 1857 (his first term began in 1868).

question:
Whose name among the following is not associated with the Revolt of 1857?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2017
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 was a major uprising against the British rule, involving both Indian sepoys and civilian leaders.
  • Many British officers tried to suppress the revolt, and several names are frequently mentioned in historical records.
  • However, Colonel St. Leger, Lieutenant Colonel Gibbs, and Colonel Wallace are not widely known or documented as major figures involved in the 1857 revolt — either as participants, suppressors, or leaders.
  • Their names are absent from standard historical accounts, suggesting they were not significantly associated with the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Famous British officers involved: General Havelock, Brigadier John Nicholson, Sir Colin Campbell.
  • Indian leaders: Mangal Pandey, Rani Laxmibai, Bahadur Shah Zafar, Tatya Tope, Kunwar Singh.
  • The revolt started in Meerut on 10 May 1857 and later spread to major centers like Delhi, Kanpur, Lucknow, and Jhansi.

question:
What was the main reason why the revolt of 1857 failed?

41st B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1996
option_1: Lack of Hindu-Muslim unity
option_2: Lack of any common plan and central organization
option_3: Limited area of its influence
option_4: Participation of the landlords
solution:
• The main reason for the failure of the Revolt of 1857 was the lack of a common plan and centralized leadership.
  • The revolt was spontaneous and uncoordinated, with different leaders acting independently.
  • There was no unified strategy or chain of command to confront the British collectively.
  • Leaders like Rani Laxmibai, Tatya Tope, Bahadur Shah Zafar, and Nana Sahib operated in isolation.
  • This made it easy for the British to suppress the revolt region by region.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt remained confined mainly to northern and central India.
  • Southern and eastern India largely remained unaffected.
  • The British advantage of superior arms, telegraph communication, and loyalty of princely states helped crush the revolt.

question:
The first freedom struggle of 1857 failed because –

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 1998
option_1: There was lack of unity of purpose among the Indian soldiers.
option_2: Most of the Indian kings supported the British government.
option_3: The British soldiers were much better equipped and organised.
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 failed due to a combination of several critical factors.
  • There was a lack of unity and coordination among the Indian rebels and soldiers.
  • Many Indian kings and princely states either remained neutral or openly supported the British.
  • The British army was better equipped, had superior weapons, disciplined troops, and used modern communication systems like the telegraph.
  • These combined reasons made it difficult for the scattered rebellion to sustain itself effectively.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt lacked a national character and was limited to certain regions.
  • No common leadership or long-term planning existed among the rebels.
  • The East India Company’s military and political control remained strong in unaffected regions, helping them suppress the rebellion quickly.

question:
Which of the following were the reasons for the failure of the revolt of 1857?

Military superiority of the British

2. The rebels did not have any unified programme and ideology

3. There was lack of support from all sections of the society

Select the correct answer using the code given below.

69th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2023
option_3: All of the above
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• Statement 1 is correct: The British possessed military superiority with advanced weapons, disciplined troops, and access to communication tools like the telegraph, which gave them a strong strategic advantage.
  • Statement 2 is correct: The rebels lacked a unified programme or ideology, and the movement remained regionally fragmented, without a clear national vision or coordinated leadership.
  • Statement 3 is correct: The revolt failed to gain support from all sections of society—many zamindars, princely states, and even common people in non-affected areas remained disinterested or loyal to the British.
  • Hence, all three statements correctly represent reasons for the failure of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The East India Company’s administrative efficiency and loyalty of certain native troops also helped the British suppress the revolt.
  • The limited geographical spread of the uprising restricted its national impact.
  • The British used divide-and-rule tactics to isolate and defeat rebel groups individually.

question:
The British were successful in suppressing the revolt of 1857 in the Rajput states because–

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 1996
option_1: The local rulers did not support the revolutionaries
option_2: The educated middle class was supporting the British
option_3: The soldiers in the cantonments were not ready to accept the leadership of revolutionaries from outside Rajputana
option_4: The newspapers were not able to show the true objectives of the revolutionaries
solution:
• The primary reason the British successfully suppressed the Revolt of 1857 in the Rajput states was that the local rulers did not support the revolutionaries.
  • Many Rajput princes and chiefs remained loyal to the British due to treaties, fear of losing privileges, or rewards promised by the colonial administration.
  • This lack of local leadership and support made it difficult for revolutionary activities to take root in the region.
  • The revolt failed to spread widely in Rajputana as a result, and British control remained intact.

Additional Information:

  • The Doctrine of Lapse was not applied harshly in Rajput states, reducing discontent among rulers.
  • The British had maintained alliances with many princely states, which they used strategically during the revolt.
  • The loyalty of princely rulers played a key role in keeping certain regions, including Rajputana, stable during the uprising.

question:
Which of the following British officers lost their lives in Lucknow?

General John Nicholson

2. General Neel

3. Major General Havelock

4. Sir Henry Lawrence

Select the correct answer using the following code–

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2008
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• General John Nicholson died during the Siege of Delhi, not Lucknow — Statement 1 is incorrect.
  • General Neill (James Neill) was killed during the relief of Lucknow in 1857 — Statement 2 is correct.
  • Major General Havelock also died in Lucknow due to dysentery shortly after the successful relief of the Residency — Statement 3 is correct.
  • Sir Henry Lawrence was the British Resident at Lucknow and was mortally wounded in an explosion during the early stages of the siege — Statement 4 is correct.
  • Hence, only statements 2, 3, and 4 are correct.

Additional Information:

  • The Siege of Lucknow was one of the most prolonged and intense events of the 1857 revolt.
  • The British forces faced stiff resistance and heavy casualties during multiple relief attempts.
  • Prominent leaders like Campbell, Havelock, and Neill were involved in military operations to reclaim Lucknow.

question:
Consider-

Assertion (K): The first freedom struggle of 1857 failed to achieve independence from the British government.

Reason (Ka): Bahadur Shah Zafar's leadership did not enjoy public support and the rulers of most of the important princely states were reluctant to support him.

Choose the correct answer in the code given below-

39th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1994
option_1: Both (K) and (Ka) are true and (Ka) is the correct explanation of (K).
option_2: Both (K) and (Ka) are true; but (Ka) is not the correct explanation of (K).
option_3: (K) is true and (Ka) is false.
option_4: (K) is false; but (Ka) is true.
solution:
• Assertion (K) is true: The Revolt of 1857 indeed failed to achieve Indian independence from British rule. Despite being widespread and intense in certain regions, it was eventually suppressed by the British.
  • Reason (Ka) is also true:Bahadur Shah Zafar, though declared the symbolic leader (Emperor of Hindustan), lacked real political and military support. Most princely states either remained neutral or supported the British.
  • The lack of unity and authoritative leadership under Zafar significantly weakened the rebellion's chances.
  • Therefore, both K and Ka are true, and Ka correctly explains K.

Additional Information:

  • Bahadur Shah Zafar was old and lacked control over the rebellious forces.
  • Rulers of states like Hyderabad, Kashmir, Gwalior (initially), and Punjab sided with the British.
  • The revolt lacked a pan-India character and suffered from fragmentation and poor coordination.

question:
Who among the following termed the Revolt of 1857 as a 'conspiracy’?

40th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1995
option_1: Sir James Outram and W. Taylor
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 was interpreted differently by various British historians and officials.
  • Sir James Outram and W. Taylor were among those who termed the revolt as a “conspiracy”, particularly emphasizing the premeditated nature of the sepoy mutiny and native discontent.
  • They believed that the uprising was not a spontaneous movement but the result of a planned plot by Indian elements against British authority.
  • Thus, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • V.A. Smith called it a sepoy mutiny, denying its national character.
  • Sir John Lawrence referred to it as a pure military mutiny.
  • T.R. Holmes described it as a Muslim conspiracy aimed at restoring the Mughal Empire.
  • Modern historians, however, view it as the first war of Indian independence with broader social, political, and economic roots.

question:
The modern historian who called the revolt of 1857 as the first war of independence was-

M.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2008
option_1: Dr. R. C. Majumdar
option_2: Dr. S. N. Sen
solution:
• The first modern historian to refer to the Revolt of 1857 as the "First War of Independence" was Vinayak Damodar Savarkar (V.D. Savarkar).
  • He presented this view in his book “The History of the First War of Indian Independence, 1857”, originally written in Marathi and later translated into English.
  • Savarkar emphasized the nationalist spirit behind the revolt and rejected the British view that it was merely a sepoy mutiny.
  • Hence, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Dr. R.C. Majumdar did not consider the revolt a national movement and believed it lacked unified leadership.
  • Dr. S.N. Sen viewed it as a revolt with mixed elements—sepoy mutiny and people's movement.
  • Ashok Mehta acknowledged the revolt's significance but did not coin the term “First War of Independence”.

question:
Who named the war of 1857 as the first freedom struggle?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2015
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• The term "First Freedom Struggle" or "First War of Indian Independence" for the Revolt of 1857 was first coined by V.D. Savarkar (Vinayak Damodar Savarkar).
  • He used this title in his book “The History of the First War of Indian Independence, 1857”, highlighting the nationalist intent and anti-colonial character of the revolt.
  • British historians like V.A. Smith and P.E. Roberts did not use such a term; instead, they referred to it as a sepoy mutiny or military rebellion.
  • Therefore, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • V.A. Smith described the revolt as a "sepoy mutiny" and denied its nationalist character.
  • P.E. Roberts viewed it as a localized rebellion without sufficient mass support.
  • Savarkar’s interpretation marked a significant shift toward an Indian nationalist historiography.

question:
By whom was the rebellion of 1857 described as the 'First Indian War of Independence’?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The rebellion of 1857 was first described as the "First Indian War of Independence" by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar (V.D. Savarkar).
  • He used this phrase in his 1909 book, originally written in Marathi, titled “The History of the First War of Indian Independence, 1857”.
  • Savarkar viewed the revolt as a national uprising against British rule, not just a military mutiny.
  • Hence, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Bal Gangadhar Tilak supported the nationalist interpretation of history but did not coin this phrase.
  • R.C. Majumdar was critical of calling it a national war; he believed the revolt lacked unity and national intent.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji focused more on economic critique of British rule and did not label the revolt as such.

question:
The official historian of the Indian independence movement was-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• The official historian of the Indian independence movement, particularly appointed by the Government of India, was Dr. S.N. Sen.
  • He was tasked with writing the official history of the 1857 revolt, and his book titled "Eighteen Fifty-Seven" was published by the Publication Division of the Government of India.
  • His interpretation was considered a balanced view, acknowledging both the sepoy revolt and the involvement of the masses.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • R.C. Majumdar had a differing view and refused to write the official history; he independently published his own critical work on the 1857 revolt.
  • Tarachand also wrote on the freedom struggle but was not the official historian.
  • V.D. Savarkar was a revolutionary and nationalist writer, not appointed officially by the government.

question:
The first Indian to write on the causes of the revolt of 1857 in an Indian language was-

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2009
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• The first Indian to write about the causes of the Revolt of 1857 in an Indian language was Syed Ahmed Khan.
  • He wrote extensively in Urdu and discussed the political and social causes behind the uprising.
  • His works provided a detailed contemporary analysis and are considered among the earliest Indian perspectives on the revolt.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • V.D. Savarkar wrote a comprehensive history of the revolt later, but in the 20th century and mostly in Marathi and English.
  • Bankim Chandra Chatterjee was a novelist and nationalist but did not specifically write a detailed account on the causes of the revolt.
  • Syed Ahmed Khan’s writings aimed at reform and understanding the socio-political environment of that time.

question:
"The so-called first national freedom struggle was neither the first nor the national nor the freedom struggle." This statement is related to-

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2010
solution:
• The statement "The so-called first national freedom struggle was neither the first nor the national nor the freedom struggle" is attributed to R.C. Majumdar.
  • He was critical of labeling the 1857 revolt as the first national freedom struggle because:
    • It was not the first major resistance against the British (there were earlier revolts).
    • It lacked pan-Indian unity and leadership, so it was not truly national.
    • It did not achieve freedom; rather, it was suppressed.
  • Majumdar’s analysis was based on detailed historical research, emphasizing the fragmented and limited nature of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • S.N. Sen provided a more balanced official view, recognizing the revolt's importance.
  • Tarachand also wrote on Indian history but did not emphasize this critique.
  • V.D. Savarkar strongly promoted the revolt as the first war of independence.

question:
Who wrote, "It is difficult to deny the conclusion that the so-called First National War of Independence of 1857 was neither the first nor a national nor a freedom struggle?"

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2017
solution:
• The statement "It is difficult to deny the conclusion that the so-called First National War of Independence of 1857 was neither the first nor a national nor a freedom struggle" was written by R.C. Majumdar.
  • Majumdar critically analyzed the 1857 revolt and argued that it lacked the characteristics of a true national freedom movement because it:
    • Was not the first resistance against British rule.
    • Lacked pan-Indian unity and leadership.
    • Did not achieve independence.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Roberts, Syed Ahmed, and Coupland also wrote about the revolt but did not express this specific critical viewpoint.
  • Majumdar’s perspective reflects a scholarly and critical historiography on the revolt.

question:
Which Indian eminent historian has not considered the revolution of 1857 as a revolution?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
solution:
• Dr. R.C. Majumdar is the eminent Indian historian who did not consider the 1857 revolt as a revolution in the true sense.
  • He viewed the event as a series of uncoordinated uprisings and mutinies, lacking a unified national character and clear revolutionary ideology.
  • Majumdar emphasized that the revolt was fragmented and limited, hence did not meet the criteria of a full-scale revolution.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Tarachand recognized it as a significant historical event but did not strongly emphasize its revolutionary character.
  • Dr. S.N. Sen saw the revolt as an important part of the independence movement.
  • V.D. Savarkar famously called it the “First War of Independence”, strongly supporting its revolutionary nature.

question:
'Indian nationalism was in its embryonic stage in the middle of the 19th century.' Historians who accept this fact –

M.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2020
option_1: Dr. R.C. Majumdar and Dr. S.N. Sen
option_2: Sir James Outram and W. Taylor
option_3: T.R. Holmes and L.E.R. Rees
option_4: Sir John Lawrence and Seeley
solution:
• The statement "Indian nationalism was in its embryonic stage in the middle of the 19th century" is accepted by Indian historians Dr. R.C. Majumdar and Dr. S.N. Sen.
  • Both historians believed that during the mid-1800s, nationalism was just beginning to emerge and was not yet a fully developed or widespread phenomenon.
  • They viewed early nationalist sentiments as limited to educated elites and not a mass movement.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • British historians like Sir James Outram, W. Taylor, T.R. Holmes, L.E.R. Rees, Sir John Lawrence, and Seeley generally denied the existence of any real nationalism at that time and often described the 1857 revolt as a mutiny or conspiracy.
  • Indian nationalism developed more strongly towards the late 19th and early 20th centuries with the formation of the Indian National Congress.

question: Which one of the following socio-religious factors significantly contributed to the outbreak of the Revolt of 1857?
option_1: Introduction of western education
option_3: Fear of religious conversion through British policies
solution:
• Among the socio-religious factors, the fear of religious conversion through British policies was a significant cause of the Revolt of 1857.
  • Many Indians, especially soldiers and peasants, feared that the British aimed to convert them forcibly to Christianity.
  • This fear was fueled by events like the activities of Christian missionaries and certain British policies seen as threatening to traditional Indian religions.
  • This suspicion and anxiety contributed greatly to the widespread unrest leading to the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The introduction of Western education created some resentment but also produced Indian reformers and leaders.
  • Widow remarriage legislation and abolition of Sati were social reforms by the British that caused resentment among orthodox sections but were less directly linked to the revolt.
  • The revolt had multiple causes, with socio-religious fears playing a key role alongside political and economic grievances.

question: Which statement best explains the military grievances that triggered the 1857 revolt?
option_1: Lack of promotion opportunities for British officers
option_2: Disparity in pay between European and Indian soldiers
option_3: Refusal to serve overseas by British troops
option_4: Introduction of sepoy pensions by the Company
solution:
• The most significant military grievance that triggered the Revolt of 1857 was the disparity in pay between European and Indian soldiers.
  • Indian sepoys were paid much less than their European counterparts despite doing similar duties.
  • This pay inequality caused resentment and lowered morale among Indian soldiers.
  • Along with other issues like lack of promotion and cultural insensitivity, this grievance fueled the anger that led to the mutiny.

Additional Information:

  • The lack of promotion opportunities for British officers was not a direct cause of the revolt.
  • British troops did not refuse to serve overseas; this issue was not relevant to Indian sepoys’ grievances.
  • The Company did not introduce sepoy pensions that could have appeased soldiers; rather, soldiers were dissatisfied with their overall treatment.

question: Who among the following leaders controlled the largest geographical area during the Revolt of 1857?
solution:
• Among the leaders listed, Nana Sahib controlled the largest geographical area during the Revolt of 1857.
  • He was the adopted son of the exiled Maratha Peshwa and led the rebellion mainly in Kanpur (Cawnpore) and surrounding regions of Central India.
  • Nana Sahib’s forces held significant territories and posed a serious challenge to the British in the region for a considerable time.
  • Other leaders like Kunwar Singh (Bihar), Rani Lakshmibai (Jhansi), and Begum Hazrat Mahal (Awadh) controlled important but relatively smaller areas.

Additional Information:

  • Nana Sahib formed a formidable resistance with support from local chieftains and sepoys.
  • The British faced severe setbacks in Kanpur due to his leadership before eventually regaining control.
  • His revolt inspired many others but was eventually suppressed by British forces.

question: What was the primary reason behind the failure of the Revolt of 1857?
option_1: Lack of international support
option_2: Absence of a common ideology and coordination among leaders
option_3: Limited number of British troops in India
option_4: Non-participation of peasants and artisans
solution:
• The primary reason behind the failure of the Revolt of 1857 was the absence of a common ideology and coordination among the leaders.
  • The revolt was marked by regional uprisings with different leaders pursuing their own goals without a unified plan.
  • This lack of central leadership and coordination prevented the rebels from effectively challenging the British forces.
  • Without a common ideology or unified command, the movement remained fragmented and was eventually crushed.

Additional Information:

  • Although international support was minimal, it was not the decisive factor in the revolt’s failure.
  • The British had a strong and well-equipped army, so the number of troops was sufficient for suppressing the revolt.
  • Many peasants and artisans did participate, but their involvement was uneven and localized, which also weakened the revolt’s impact.

question: Which one of the following British responses came immediately after the suppression of the Revolt of 1857?
option_1: Introduction of Morley-Minto reforms
option_2: Formation of the Indian National Congress
option_3: Passing of the Government of India Act, 1858
solution:
• The immediate British response after the suppression of the Revolt of 1857 was the passing of the Government of India Act, 1858.
  • This act marked the end of the East India Company's rule and transferred the administration of India directly to the British Crown.
  • The act aimed to reorganize the governance of India and prevent future rebellions by restructuring the political framework.
  • Hence, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The Morley-Minto Reforms were introduced much later in 1909 to provide limited Indian participation in governance.
  • The Indian National Congress was formed in 1885 as a platform for political dialogue and reform.
  • The Partition of Bengal occurred in 1905 and was a controversial move aimed at administrative convenience but sparked widespread protests.

question: What was the strategic significance of Delhi during the Revolt of 1857?
option_1: Base of sepoy recruitment
option_2: Headquarters of the East India Company
option_3: Symbolic seat of the Mughal Emperor
solution:
• The strategic significance of Delhi during the Revolt of 1857 was primarily because it was the symbolic seat of the Mughal Emperor.
  • Delhi was the capital of the Mughal Empire, and Bahadur Shah Zafar, the last Mughal emperor, was declared the leader of the rebellion.
  • Capturing Delhi gave the rebels a legitimate political authority and helped unify various groups under the banner of restoring Mughal sovereignty.
  • Hence, option (c) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Delhi was not a major base for sepoy recruitment; recruitment was spread across various regions.
  • The headquarters of the East India Company was in Calcutta (Kolkata), not Delhi.
  • Although Delhi had economic importance, its main role in the revolt was political and symbolic, not primarily economic.

question: Which princely state ruler supported the British during the Revolt and was rewarded with a title?
solution:
• The Nizam of Hyderabad supported the British during the Revolt of 1857.
  • He remained loyal and provided military assistance to the British forces in suppressing the rebellion.
  • As a result of his support, the Nizam was rewarded with titles and maintained his princely status under British rule.
  • Other options such as Rani of Jhansi, Begum Hazrat Mahal, and Nana Sahib actively opposed the British.
  • Therefore, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Hyderabad was one of the largest and most powerful princely states in India, and its support was crucial for the British.
  • The loyalty of certain princely states helped the British maintain control during the rebellion.
  • The British continued to use such alliances as part of their "Divide and Rule" policy.

question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the Revolt of 1857?
option_1: It was the first war of Indian independence
option_2: It was limited to northern and central India
option_3: It had strong support from Indian industrialists
option_4: It was suppressed due to British military superiority
solution:
• The incorrect statement regarding the Revolt of 1857 is that it had strong support from Indian industrialists (option c).
  • In reality, the revolt did not have significant support from Indian industrialists, as India’s industrial sector was still in its early stages and many industrialists preferred stability under British rule.
  • Statements (a), (b), and (d) are generally accepted:
    • It is often called the first war of Indian independence (though debated).
    • It was mostly limited to northern and central India.
    • It was suppressed due to British military superiority and better organization.
  • Hence, option (c) is incorrect.

Additional Information:

  • Indian industrialists emerged more prominently in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
  • The revolt was mainly supported by soldiers, peasants, landlords, and some sections of the urban population.
  • The British used superior military resources and strategy to suppress the rebellion.
